elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Based on IP, H2oba ligands and different metals, two novel complexes were hydrothermally constructed, {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1), {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2). In complex 1 two same chiral sheets exhibit rare 2D→2D parallel interpenetration with the   P   1   ¯     space group. Complex 2 contains 1D left-hand helical chains and dissociated right-hand helical chains with the C2 space group. Two complexes exhibit good thermal stability.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► Two complexes base on Cd and Mn and two different types of ligands. ► A rare 2D→2D parallel interpenetration were found in complex 1. ► The good fluorescence properties were shown.

Abstract

Based on 1H-imidazo[4,5-f][1,10]-phenanthroline (IP), 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid) (H2oba), and two different metal salts, two novel complexes were hydrothermally constructed, {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1) and {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2). Complex 1 exhibits a rare 2D→2D parallel interpenetration layer , which contains two same-hand chiral sheets with the   P   1   ¯     space group. Complex 2 contains 1D left-hand helical chain with the C2 space group. Meanwhile, the dissociate oba and water molecules are connected to be a right-hand helical chain via hydrogen bonds, and form a twofold-interpenetrating structure. In addition, the two compounds also exhibit good thermal stability.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently been well developed, arising not only from their intriguing ability to form variety of architectures and topologies but also due to their potential applications . Lots of intriguing architectures, such as the common catenated arrays (interpenetration, self-penetration) and the more complexes molecular species (polycatenanes, polyrotaxanes and polyknots) are being on research . The final structure of coordination complex depends on geometrical and electronic property of the metal ion and the multitopic organic ligands. The type (solid or flexible, end-capping or bridged), size and length of the ligands are very important for synthesizing diverse complexes. However, during the construction of complexes, a lot of external factors, such as temperature, solvent, the metal-to-ligand ratio and pH value of the solution, also play important roles .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently been well developed, arising not only from their intriguing ability to form variety of architectures and topologies but also due to their potential applications . Lots of intriguing architectures, such as the common catenated arrays (interpenetration, self-penetration) and the more complexes molecular species (polycatenanes, polyrotaxanes and polyknots) are being on research . The final structure of coordination complex depends on geometrical and electronic property of the metal ion and the multitopic organic ligands. The type (solid or flexible, end-capping or bridged), size and length of the ligands are very important for synthesizing diverse complexes. However, during the construction of complexes, a lot of external factors, such as temperature, solvent, the metal-to-ligand ratio and pH value of the solution, also play important roles .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Among the various organic ligands, 1,10-phen has been widely used in constructing functional MOFs, however, its derivative of 1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-imidazo[4,5-<ce:italic>f</ce:italic>][1,10]-phenanthroline (IP) is rarely studied. IP can be a good building block because of the following considerations : (1) it can act both a hydrogen-bond acceptor and a hydrogen-bond donor; (2) IP ligand has four potential coordination sites, which can lead to the higher dimensional structures; (3) the electron-rich rings of IP indicate that its metal complexes may have the potential to form electrical conductors and fluorescent materials; (4) the phenanthroline ring in IP may construct biological activity; (5) the π–π stacking interactions between the aromatic rings in IP ligand facilitate ordered, non-inter penetrating or low-dimension interpenetrating networks. In our earlier research, we have constructed a series of novel complexes using IP with aromatic carboxylates, 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoic acid, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, fumaric acid, 3,3′,4,4′-benzophenonetetracarboxylic acid and 1,4′-benzendicarboxylic acid .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Among the various organic ligands, 1,10-phen has been widely used in constructing functional MOFs, however, its derivative of 1H-imidazo[4,5-f][1,10]-phenanthroline (IP) is rarely studied. IP can be a good building block because of the following considerations : (1) it can act both a hydrogen-bond acceptor and a hydrogen-bond donor; (2) IP ligand has four potential coordination sites, which can lead to the higher dimensional structures; (3) the electron-rich rings of IP indicate that its metal complexes may have the potential to form electrical conductors and fluorescent materials; (4) the phenanthroline ring in IP may construct biological activity; (5) the π-π stacking interactions between the aromatic rings in IP ligand facilitate ordered, non-inter penetrating or low-dimension interpenetrating networks. In our earlier research, we have constructed a series of novel complexes using IP with aromatic carboxylates, 4,4'-sulfonyldibenzoic acid, pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, fumaric acid, 3,3',4,4'-benzophenonetetracarboxylic acid and 1,4'-benzendicarboxylic acid .

In this work, based on the two different types of metal salts, under the same hydrothermal synthesize method, it obtained two complexes, namely {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1) and {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2). elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Reagents and physical measurements

All the employed reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Infrared spectra on KBr pellets were recorded on Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrophotometer in the range of 4000-400cm-1. Thermal analyses were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 under N2 atmosphere. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded with a Pigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer.

elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data collection and refinement

Single-crystal diffraction data of 1 and 2 were collected on the Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å) at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and successive Fourier difference synthesis (shelxs-97) , and refined using the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms (shelxl-97) . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined using a riding model. Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for 1 and 2 are summarized in  . Selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations for 1 and 2 are listed in Table S1 (Supporting information).

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and coordination modes

The two complexes, {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1) and {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2), have quite different structures, the structural details are described on below. The synthesize method and the ligand coordination modes are shown in  . The carboxyl ions of coordinated oba are bi-dentate in 1, and monodentate in 2. The IP exhibit two coordinated sites in 1 and 2, using two nitrogen atoms from phenanthroline ring. But in 1, another half of IP molecules are using the third nitrogen atom, act as bridge ligands.

Cd1 exhibits contorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry, which is seven-coordinated and by four O atoms (O1, O2, O6, O7) from two bidentate bridged oba ligands, one N atom (N4) from one bridged IP ligand, and two phenanthroline N atoms (N5, N6) from one IP ligand, [Cd1–O 2.378(3)–2.441(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cd1–N 2.341(3)–2.424(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å]. Cd2 ion is also seven-coordinated with four O atoms (O4, O5, O9 and O10) from two bidentate bridged oba ligands, one O atom (O12) from one water ligand, and two phenanthroline N atoms (N1 and N2) from the bridged IP ligand, [Cd2–O 2.290(3)–2.455(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cd2–N 2.343(3)–2.453(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å]. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, Cd1 and Cd2 ions are alternately bridged by oba ligand to construct right-hand helical chains with a pitch of 24.906<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the right-hand helical chains are bridged by the IP molecules to form the 2D chiral sheet (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Omitting the coordinated water and IP molecules, and simplifying the bridged IP ligands as the single green lines, the right chiral chains are shown clearly. As previous researches, many complexes containing the 2D meso-helical sheet consisting of alternant left-handed and right-handed helical chains have been reported , but the 2D helical sheet with only one type of helical chains is quite rare . Interestingly, the two right-handed helical chains, from the two nets, revolved around the same axis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). In our previous work, we had successfully reported a complex contains single-helical 2D sheets exhibiting 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2D parallel interpenetration  which is the first example of 4-crossing [2]-catenane, and in the two (4,4) interpenetrated sheets, one sheet is left-hand, the other sheet is right-hand. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the two 2D sheets, with (6,3) topology, also interpenetrate forming a 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2D parallel type. However, the 2D homochiral interpenetrating layer containing double-stranded single-handed helices is very infrequent . The interpenetrated motif is 2-crossing [2]-catenane (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>), Then interpenetrated 2D layers, left-hand and right-hand layers stacking alternately, with a sequence of ABAB, forming the 3D array (Fig. S1). The 2D chiral structure with polycatenane characters has been reported in some references . However, the IP molecular in complexes exhibits end-capping ligand. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and another complex in the early research , IP ligand used its third coordinate site to be a bridge ligand, it is very rare.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

The X-ray single-crystal structural analysis shows that complex 1 is a 2D-layer, crystallized in the triclinic   P   1   ¯     space group. The asymmetric unit contains two independent Cd(II) centers, two de-protonated oba, two IP, one coordinated water molecule and one crystallization water molecule ( ). Cd1 exhibits contorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry, which is seven-coordinated and by four O atoms (O1, O2, O6, O7) from two bidentate bridged oba ligands, one N atom (N4) from one bridged IP ligand, and two phenanthroline N atoms (N5, N6) from one IP ligand, [Cd1-O 2.378(3)-2.441(3)Å, Cd1-N 2.341(3)-2.424(3)Å]. Cd2 ion is also seven-coordinated with four O atoms (O4, O5, O9 and O10) from two bidentate bridged oba ligands, one O atom (O12) from one water ligand, and two phenanthroline N atoms (N1 and N2) from the bridged IP ligand, [Cd2-O 2.290(3)-2.455(3)Å, Cd2-N 2.343(3)-2.453(3)Å]. In 1, Cd1 and Cd2 ions are alternately bridged by oba ligand to construct right-hand helical chains with a pitch of 24.906Å, and the right-hand helical chains are bridged by the IP molecules to form the 2D chiral sheet ( ). Omitting the coordinated water and IP molecules, and simplifying the bridged IP ligands as the single green lines, the right chiral chains are shown clearly. As previous researches, many complexes containing the 2D meso-helical sheet consisting of alternant left-handed and right-handed helical chains have been reported , but the 2D helical sheet with only one type of helical chains is quite rare . Interestingly, the two right-handed helical chains, from the two nets, revolved around the same axis ( ). In our previous work, we had successfully reported a complex contains single-helical 2D sheets exhibiting 2D→2D parallel interpenetration  which is the first example of 4-crossing [2]-catenane, and in the two (4,4) interpenetrated sheets, one sheet is left-hand, the other sheet is right-hand. In complex 1 the two 2D sheets, with (6,3) topology, also interpenetrate forming a 2D→2D parallel type. However, the 2D homochiral interpenetrating layer containing double-stranded single-handed helices is very infrequent . The interpenetrated motif is 2-crossing [2]-catenane ( ), Then interpenetrated 2D layers, left-hand and right-hand layers stacking alternately, with a sequence of ABAB, forming the 3D array (Fig. S1). The 2D chiral structure with polycatenane characters has been reported in some references . However, the IP molecular in complexes exhibits end-capping ligand. In complex 1 and another complex in the early research , IP ligand used its third coordinate site to be a bridge ligand, it is very rare.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Crystal structure of {[Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(IP)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(oba)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">When changing the cadmium salts to manganese salts, under the same synthesis condition, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is obtained, which contains 1D chiral zigzag chain with the <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 space group. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has two crystallographically independent Mn(II) atoms, four coordinated IP ligands, two monodentate coordinated oba ligands, one crystallization oba and two water molecules of crystallization (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). Both Mn1 and Mn2 atoms are six-coordinated by four N atoms from two phenanthroline units of two IP ligands, and two O (Ow9 and Ow10) atoms from two bridged oba ligands, [Mn–N 2.247(3)–2.379(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Mn–O 2.114(3)–2.162(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å]. The Mn(II) atom is bridge-connected by oba molecules, forming a 1D left-hand chiral chain along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis plane, with a pitch of 16.636<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Then, a 2D left-hand chiral layer is formed by the π–π stacking interactions between the pyridine rings of IP molecules in the nearest two chains with the centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.643<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). Interestingly, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have two water molecules of crystallization and an uncoordinated oba molecule as guest molecules, via hydrogen interactions between O9, O10, and two O6 atoms from oba molecules, connected to be a right-hand chiral chain along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (O6⋯O10 is 2.575<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, O9⋯O10 is 2.663<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and O9⋯O9 is 2.897<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>), the pitch is 14.844<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. They are oblique interpenetrated into 2D layers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). The hydrogen bonds between N atoms (N4 and N7 atoms in IP from the 2D layers) and O atoms (Ow9 and Ow10 atoms from the right-hand helical crystallization chains) connected two types of 1D helical chains to be 3D network (N4⋯O9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, N7⋯O10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.756<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (Fig. S2a). Besides, the π–π stacking interactions also play an important role to stabilize the 3D framework. Then, the 3D framework further exhibits a twofold-interpenetration (Fig. S2b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2)

When changing the cadmium salts to manganese salts, under the same synthesis condition, complex 2 is obtained, which contains 1D chiral zigzag chain with the C2 space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 has two crystallographically independent Mn(II) atoms, four coordinated IP ligands, two monodentate coordinated oba ligands, one crystallization oba and two water molecules of crystallization ( ). Both Mn1 and Mn2 atoms are six-coordinated by four N atoms from two phenanthroline units of two IP ligands, and two O (Ow9 and Ow10) atoms from two bridged oba ligands, [Mn-N 2.247(3)-2.379(3)Å, Mn-O 2.114(3)-2.162(3)Å]. The Mn(II) atom is bridge-connected by oba molecules, forming a 1D left-hand chiral chain along the a and b axis plane, with a pitch of 16.636Å. Then, a 2D left-hand chiral layer is formed by the π-π stacking interactions between the pyridine rings of IP molecules in the nearest two chains with the centroid-to-centroid distance of 3.643Å ( ). Interestingly, 2 have two water molecules of crystallization and an uncoordinated oba molecule as guest molecules, via hydrogen interactions between O9, O10, and two O6 atoms from oba molecules, connected to be a right-hand chiral chain along the c axis (O6⋯O10 is 2.575Å, O9⋯O10 is 2.663Å, and O9⋯O9 is 2.897Å) ( ), the pitch is 14.844Å. They are oblique interpenetrated into 2D layers ( ). The hydrogen bonds between N atoms (N4 and N7 atoms in IP from the 2D layers) and O atoms (Ow9 and Ow10 atoms from the right-hand helical crystallization chains) connected two types of 1D helical chains to be 3D network (N4⋯O9=3.000Å, N7⋯O10=2.756Å) (Fig. S2a). Besides, the π-π stacking interactions also play an important role to stabilize the 3D framework. Then, the 3D framework further exhibits a twofold-interpenetration (Fig. S2b).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>PXRD studies and thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The phase purity of the bulk materials of two complexes were conformed by comparison of the power diffraction patterns with that calculated from the single-crystal study (Figs. S3–S4).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The two complexes are air-stable, can retain their crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. To characterize the thermal stability of the two complexes, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) have been carried out. TGA result shows that the frameworks of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the lattice and coordinated water are lost (observed: 3.1%, calculates: 2.97%). The complex collapses in the temperature range of 360-992<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The residue substance is 21.4% (the calculated CdO weight is 21.17%). Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the coordinated water, lattice water and lattice oba ligand are lost when the temperature up to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (observed: 11.8%, calculates: 16.37%). The frameworks stable up to 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the complex discomposes continuously from 350 to 795<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The resistant weight is 9.8% (the calculated MnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is 9.67%) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
PXRD studies and thermal analyses

The phase purity of the bulk materials of two complexes were conformed by comparison of the power diffraction patterns with that calculated from the single-crystal study (Figs. S3-S4).

The two complexes are air-stable, can retain their crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. To characterize the thermal stability of the two complexes, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) have been carried out. TGA result shows that the frameworks of complex 1 is stable up to 360°C, the lattice and coordinated water are lost (observed: 3.1%, calculates: 2.97%). The complex collapses in the temperature range of 360-992°C. The residue substance is 21.4% (the calculated CdO weight is 21.17%). Complex 2 shows the coordinated water, lattice water and lattice oba ligand are lost when the temperature up to 160°C (observed: 11.8%, calculates: 16.37%). The frameworks stable up to 350°C, the complex discomposes continuously from 350 to 795°C. The resistant weight is 9.8% (the calculated MnO2 is 9.67%) ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Photoluminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The emission spectrums of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in the solid state were investigated at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>). The fluorescent spectrum of IP showed a relatively broad band at 460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>315<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) , while there is no obvious emission observed for the free oba ligand under the same experimental conditions . Both the two complexes, when excitation at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm produced week fluorescent emission peaks at about 468<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, near the IP emission band. The fluorescent emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 516<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, may therefore be attributed to charge transfer transition between the ligands and cadmium centers (LMCT) . The significant redshift of the band in contrast to that of IP ligand can be attributed to the metal-ligand coordination interactions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties

The emission spectrums of complex 1 and 2 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature ( ). The fluorescent spectrum of IP showed a relatively broad band at 460nm (λ ex =315nm) , while there is no obvious emission observed for the free oba ligand under the same experimental conditions . Both the two complexes, when excitation at 300nm produced week fluorescent emission peaks at about 468nm, near the IP emission band. The fluorescent emissions of 1 at 516nm, may therefore be attributed to charge transfer transition between the ligands and cadmium centers (LMCT) . The significant redshift of the band in contrast to that of IP ligand can be attributed to the metal-ligand coordination interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In summary, we have synthesized two novel complexes, {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(IP)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(IP)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(oba)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), which exhibit different type of structures. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a rare 2D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2D parallel interpenetration layer constructed from two same kind of chiral sheets, the 2D parallel interpenetrated layer is chiral, and the two interpenetrated sheets are all same left (or right) chiral. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains 1D right-hand helical chains and dissociate oblique interpenetrate oba-water left-hand helical chains.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have synthesized two novel complexes, {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1) and {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2), which exhibit different type of structures. Complex 1 is a rare 2D→2D parallel interpenetration layer constructed from two same kind of chiral sheets, the 2D parallel interpenetrated layer is chiral, and the two interpenetrated sheets are all same left (or right) chiral. Complex 2 contains 1D right-hand helical chains and dissociate oblique interpenetrate oba-water left-hand helical chains.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The outcome should owning to the different types of metals, Cd(II) has a larger ion radius, it shows more coordinated sites. So complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals 2D structure, and the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> appears 1D chains. This result may offer the new insights into the controlling of assembly chiral coordination frameworks. Further research is under way.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The outcome should owning to the different types of metals, Cd(II) has a larger ion radius, it shows more coordinated sites. So complex 1 reveals 2D structure, and the complex 2 appears 1D chains. This result may offer the new insights into the controlling of assembly chiral coordination frameworks. Further research is under way.

Synthesis of {[Cd2(oba)2(IP)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

The synthesis of complex 1: a mixture of Cd(Ac)2⋅2H2O (0.2mmol), H2oba (0.3mmol), IP (0.3mmol), H2O (6mL) and CH3OH(6mL) was stirred at room temperature for 2h. The solution was putted into the Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25mL), sealed and heated up to 160°C, maintained for 72h. Then it slowly cooled down to room temperature, yellow crystals were obtained. Yield: 58%. Anal. Calc. for C27H18CdN4O6: C, 53.48; H, 2.99; N, 9.24. Found: C, 53.43; H, 2.99; N, 9.23%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3417(m), 3068(w), 1652(s), 1595(s), 1531(m), 1387(s), 1301(w), 1232(s), 1158(m), 1076(m), 1009(w), 946(m), 877(m), 806(m), 773(m), 733(m), 691(w), 637(m), 613(w), 522(w), 499(w).

Synthesis of {[Mn2(IP)4(oba)2]⋅(oba)(H2O)2} n  (2)

The synthesis method of complex 2 was similar to 1, yellow crystals were obtained. Yield: 53%. Anal. Calc. for C94H60Mn2N16O19: C, 61.73; H, 3.12; N, 12.21. Found: C, 61.78; H, 2.99; N, 3.31%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3445(m), 3125(w), 2859(w), 1919(w), 1694(s), 1597(s), 1559(s), 1497(m), 1397(s), 1354(s), 1239(s), 1156(s), 1072(w), 1009(w), 934(m), 875(m), 850(w), 815(w), 778(m), 733(w), 698(w), 634(w), 539(w), 512(w), 493(w).

cln_elements.clean_text:
PXRD studies and thermal analyses

The phase purity of the bulk materials of two complexes were conformed by comparison of the power diffraction patterns with that calculated from the single-crystal study (Figs. S3-S4).

The two complexes are air-stable, can retain their crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. To characterize the thermal stability of the two complexes, thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) have been carried out. TGA result shows that the frameworks of complex 1 is stable up to 360°C, the lattice and coordinated water are lost (observed: 3.1%, calculates: 2.97%). The complex collapses in the temperature range of 360-992°C. The residue substance is 21.4% (the calculated CdO weight is 21.17%). Complex 2 shows the coordinated water, lattice water and lattice oba ligand are lost when the temperature up to 160°C (observed: 11.8%, calculates: 16.37%). The frameworks stable up to 350°C, the complex discomposes continuously from 350 to 795°C. The resistant weight is 9.8% (the calculated MnO2 is 9.67%) ( ).

Photoluminescence properties

The emission spectrums of complex 1 and 2 in the solid state were investigated at room temperature ( ). The fluorescent spectrum of IP showed a relatively broad band at 460nm (λ ex =315nm) , while there is no obvious emission observed for the free oba ligand under the same experimental conditions . Both the two complexes, when excitation at 300nm produced week fluorescent emission peaks at about 468nm, near the IP emission band. The fluorescent emissions of 1 at 516nm, may therefore be attributed to charge transfer transition between the ligands and cadmium centers (LMCT) . The significant redshift of the band in contrast to that of IP ligand can be attributed to the metal-ligand coordination interactions.
